did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The World War I Collection contains information relating to the participation of Georgetown residents in World War I.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The United States declared war on Germany and joined World War I on April 6, 1917. The conflict ended a year and a half later on November 11, 1918.

A total of 34 men and women from Georgetown served in a military capacity during the war. According to the Service records: Connecticut men and women in the armed forces of the United States during World War, 1917-1920, their names were:

Anderson, Hubert Theodore; Anderson, Karl A.; Barrett, Harry; Beecher, Thomas S.; Bennett, Sarah Isabel; Bennett, Elsie Dorman; Bennett, Clinton H.; Bouton, Floyd B., Jr.; Connery, Harold J.; Dayton, James W.; Dayton, Theodore Reed; Dougherty, Marcus; Foster, John W.; Frederickson, Charles R.; Frederickson, Hubert Robert; Glans, Harold E.; Holmes, Henry T.; Karlson, August W.; Keeler, Hawley S.; Kramer, Herbert L.; Kramer, Otto Frederick; Liedberg, Eric T.; Lindelof, John Albert; Lindstrom, Harry Victor; Lockwood, William; Masterson, Charles; McIlwain, Robert William; Melsbach, Frank Leonard; Wilson, Cark Elof; Perry, Lewis Webb; Peterson, Frank Gust; Sherwood, Cecil Edmond; Sundquist, Eric Gunnar; Tritto, Guiseppe Dominick.
The war claimed the lives of two Georgetown servicemen: Charles R. Frederickson and August W. Karlson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The World War I Collection is a small collection including a few photographs, books, pamphlets, a poster, and a piece of sheet music. The most important item in the collection is a letter - apparently a love letter - sent by a French woman, Blanche Velley, to Harold J. Connery in 1919.
